rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:54–64
rsbNotes.text: 78:54–64 God blessed them with the Promised Land, but they quickly forgot Him.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:56
rsbNotes.text: 78:56 tested and rebelled against the Most High God. They did not keep His law in the desert, nor did they keep it in the Promised Land. See Judg. 2:10–15.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:58
rsbNotes.text: 78:58 with their idols. The height of their rebellion was to worship false gods.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:60
rsbNotes.text: 78:60 dwelling at Shiloh. Soon after entering the Promised Land, the tabernacle was set up in Shiloh (Josh. 18:1), twenty miles northeast of Jerusalem, in the tribal territory of Ephraim.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:61
rsbNotes.text: 78:61 his power to captivity. During Samuel’s youth, God punished Israel and its leaders, particularly Eli’s sons, by abandoning Israel in battle and allowing the Philistines to capture the ark (1 Sam. 4; 5).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:65
rsbNotes.text: 78:65 as from sleep. God had left Israel temporarily and seemed to be asleep. An unusual figure of speech explains how He began to act.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:67
rsbNotes.text: 78:67 He rejected. The rejection of the tribe of Ephraim refers to the abandonment of the Shiloh sanctuary, and perhaps also the rejection of Saul’s monarchy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:68
rsbNotes.text:
78:68 but he chose the tribe of Judah. Jerusalem succeeded Shiloh as the designated location for the worship of God.

Mount Zion. See note Ps. 2:6.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:70
rsbNotes.text: 78:70 sheepfolds. This verse recalls David’s humble origins (1 Sam. 16:11–13).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:72
rsbNotes.text: 78:72 upright heart. The psalm climaxes on a positive note with a faithful king in Jerusalem, the place of God’s special presence.
